body: Frederick Eaton elected mayor of LA. He appoints his friend, William Mulholland, as superintendent of the LADWP
title: Frederick Eaton Elected Mayor of Los Angeles
caption: Portrait of former Los Angeles Mayor Fred Eaton during his time in office from 1898-1900.

body: The population of Los Angeles more than tripled between 1900 and 1910, from 102,500 to 319,200.
title: Los Angeles Population Boom
caption: Early photograph of Los Angeles was taken at the northwest corner of Second and Broadway.

body: After approval by LA’s Board of Water Commissioners, William Mulholland, Fred Eaton and their team head to the Owens Valley to search for viable new water sources.
title: Mullholland and Eaton Head to Owens Valley
caption: William Mulholland, the chief engineer for building of the Los Angeles Aqueduct, in the field with his surveying instrument.

body: L.A. voters approve a $1.5 million bond to purchase land, water rights needed to start the Aqueduct project.
title: LA Voters Approve $1.5 Million Bond

body: Eaton and Mulholland acquire enough land and water rights in Owens Valley to block Bureau of Reclamation's planned irrigation project.
title: Sufficient Land Acquired in Owens Valley
caption: The Owens River before water was diverted to feed the L.A. Aqueduct.

body: The three fathers of the aqueduct, Joseph B. Lippincott, Fred Eaton and William Mulholland, meet to consider their plans.
title: Aqueduct Plans Take Shape
caption: (L-R) Joseph B. Lippincott, Fred Eaton and William Mulholland

body: Second bond was passed with a budget of $24.5 million to fund the project.
title: A Second Bond Measure of $24.5 Million Passed

body: Construction of the LA Aqueduct begins in the Owens Valley.
title: Construction Begins
caption: Concreting open lined section of Los Angeles Aqueduct

body: Cottonwood Power Plant started generating 900 kilowatts of hydroelectric power along the Los Angeles Aqueduct on November 13, 1908, supplying energy to run equipment during the Aqueduct construction from Owens Valley through the Mojave Desert.
title: Cottonwood Power Plant Started
caption: Cottonwood Power Plant starts generating hydroelectric power to run construction equipment, A second unit was added in 1909.

body: Monolith cement plant and camp built to house workers and produce enough concrete to line the L.A. Aqueduct.
title: Monolith Cement Plant and Camp Built
caption: Monolith Cement Plant (LADWP)

body: The Elizabeth Tunnel sets world record for rock tunnel driving, 604 feet in one month. The tunnel spanned more than five miles upon completion.
title: The Record-Breaking Elizabeth Tunnel Built
caption: Workers pose at the portal of the Elizabeth Tunnel, just north of the San Fernando Valley, where workers set a record for hard-rock drilling.

body: The first Caterpillar tractors used to haul building materials out to the construction sites.
title: First Use of Caterpillar Tractors
caption: Two "caterpillar" tractors pull a long wagon train in the Mojave Desert during construction of the LA Aqueduct. (LADWP)

body: Caterpillar tractors replaced with mule teams. Terrain proved too tough for automotive travel at the time.
title: Mule Teams Used to Haul Equipment
caption: Huge 30-ton sections of steel pipe used in construction of the Jawbone Siphon section of the original Los Angeles-Owens River Aqueduct were transported over rough desert terrain by 52-mule team wagons. (LADWP)

body: More than 15,000 tons of steel were used by the time the Siphon is finally completed in 1913.
title: Construction of Jawbone Siphon Completed
caption: Construction of the Jawbone Siphon (LADWP)

body: Los Angeles Aqueduct officially dedicated, Mulholland proclaims, “there it is, take it!” By the end, the construction of the Aqueduct required more than 2,000 workers and 164 tunnels
title: L.A. Aqueduct Officially Opens
caption: View of “Cascades” marking the terminus of Los Angeles Aqueduct at the southern end of the Newhall Pass in what would be present day Sylmar on November 5, 1913. (LADWP)

body: Dubbed the “Owens Valley War,” 70 armed men seized control of an Aqueduct gate and shut off the water flow. Protesters would attempt to destroy parts of the Aqueduct several times over the years as resources began to dwindle in the area.
title: Start of Owens Valley War
caption: Two men examining kit of dynamite and wire found during sabotage incidents of Owens Valley Aqueduct, Calif., circa 1924

body: Owens Lake completely dried due to water diversion
title: Owens Lake Dries Up

body: Vandals float two cases of blasting gelatin down the No Name siphon, One case explodes, tearing a gaping hole in the metal, but the other case fails to detonate.
title: No Name Siphon Bombed
caption: Siphon damaged by dynamite blast in 1927.

body: The Inyo County Bank collapses after its owners, the Watterson brothers, leaders in the anti-aqueduct movement, are charged with embezzlement. Collapse of the bank wipes out businesses and life savings of many Owens Valley residents. It also ends the efforts of local aqueduct protesters.
title: Inyo County Bank Collapses
caption: (L-R) Mark Q. Watterson, W.W. Watterson, A.D. Schively. Inside the Inyo County Bank.

body: By this time, L.A. has seized almost all water from the Owens Valley. Agriculture in the area ceases to exist.
title: LA Owns 90 Percent of Owens Valley Water Rights

body: St. Francis Dam in northern LA County burst, inundating the towns of Castaic Junction, Fillmore, Bardsdale and Piru with billions of gallons of water and drowning hundreds of residents.
title: St. Francis Dam Collapse
caption: St. Francis Dam in San Francisquito Canyon near Saugus was completed in 1926 and failed in 1928. It was part of the Owens Valley Aqueduct System. This post-failure photograph shows several men looking very small as they stand in the area below the failed dam. One large chunk of dam remains standing while another lays on the ground below it.

body: Mulholland was largely blamed for the St. Francis Dam tragedy. If effectively ended his long career with the LADWP.
title: Mulholland Resigns from LADWP
caption: Portrait of William Mulholland.

body: A second L.A. Aqueduct extends the original, adding 137 miles of piping.
title: LADWP Completes Second Aqueduct Extension
caption: Department surveyors using plane table, plot topography for Second Aqueduct route in 1971.
